instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SSD_PWR_EN: What is SSD_PWR_EN? SSD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip making the power rail for the SSD to turn on when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no SSD
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that does not recognize the SSD. First, it wasen't booting the macos (freezed in the loading bar), and after the CleanME upgrade, the SSD is not recognized any more, even with a known good SSD.

On SSD connector J3700, I have 3.3V on all pins of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FLT</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>SSD_SR_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.2V

<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V

I have 3.2V on <RESISTOR>R1620</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> , so I think that it is not the CPU (don't know if it makes sense).

I think that it might be <CHIP>U8070</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U3711</CHIP> or <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>.

On <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> I have 3.2V on <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> , but on <CHIP>U3711</CHIP> I think that I have 0V on <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> pin 1

Shall I replace <CHIP>U3711</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no SSD
threads.message:
"I [U]think[/U] that I have"
What this mean, you are not sure about measurment???

If trace is broken , run a wire to fix the problem.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no SSD
threads.message:
Hi,

I said  "I think" because I wasn't sure that I was reaching correctly the pin under the chip. But after all I do have continuity bettewn <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3711</CHIP>, and the 3.2V on pin 1 of <CHIP>U3711</CHIP> and 3.2V on <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> in J3700.

Not sure if it was the BIOS or a bad contact on <CHIP>U3711</CHIP>, but after restored the original BIOS, the mac now recognizes the disk, but freezes on the loading bar, even with another disk.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no SSD
threads.message:
You had APFS issue, after flashing BIOS without APFS support.
I supposed that, but you've said just clean ME, not full BIOS; post accurate information in the future.
You also left unclear if <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> line wasn't broken.

Now is time to clean ME of your BIOS; or flash new one (clean ME), with APFS support.
You also have the option to install High Sierra into empty internal SSD, to get APFS support with the other BIOS tried.
